ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a great deal about medieval history, the Catholic Church, theology, theocracy, architecture, and state building in medieval France
An understanding of French gothic history, architectural terms of cathedrals, religious imagery, and medieval philosophy.
An in-depth knowledge of Paris cathedrals, culture, history and literature. I also learned how to write precisely.
I learned lots about religion, architecture, and French history,
Knowledge into the era of medieval history and the age of gothic cathedrals as well as gothic architecture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Lots of really interesting history, really multi-disciplinarian, incredibly comprehensive
Weaknesses: A hefty amount of reading

Strengths: the excursions are interesting 
Weaknesses: There are quite a few in my opinion. So much time is devoted to simply clicking through slideshows of the very same works of art that would be viewed on excursion. Class often felt unnecessarily long and I would have preferred more time for discussion and less time simply watching slides click by.

There are no weaknesses with this course. The class and excursion times were perfectly organized, and the class size allowed for productive discussion which, alongside a knowledgable professor like Howard Bloch, made for an education unlike any other.
Nothing but strengths

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Most definitely! Whether youre a humanities major who wants to learn more about architecture or a Social Science major who wants to learn more about medival history or any other type of major who just wants some history and literature in your life, this is a great course!

Honestly I would not. To any student reading this in the future I would say find any other reason to visit Paris. This course was spent almost entirely sitting in a class room as the professor lectured for three hours with little room for discussion.

Yes, it's worth it. Howard Bloch has a seemingly infinite, encyclopedic knowledge of France, and even if you aren't a history or English major, it is nonetheless a valuable class for its ability to train precise, intent writers (a skill that everyone needs).
Yes, it's a fantastic course in a fantastic location.
Yes, I think it was very interesting course material and the class was well organized.

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.
comments: Agree

Agree

Agree

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: I will definitely look at theocracy in a much different light as well as the early modern history of the Catholic Church. It certainly made me re-examine my own spirituality in a very interesting way.
Could be an interesting cocktail discussion. Not much more.
I'll use the skills of precise writing I've cultivated, and will be thinking about the valuable insights Professor Bloch gave for the rest of my life.

extras.title: FREN S304 01/HSAR S428 01/HUMS S268 01/LITR S177 01 - Age of Cathedrals
